standard_metadata.standard_description: Represent real world and mathematical problems by graphing points in the first quadrant of the coordinate plane, and interpret coordinate values of points in the context of the situation.

hints.content: The **ordered pair** of a point tells us how to get to it from the origin.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{array}{cc} (\blueD{\text{distance right}},& \greenD{\text{distance up}})\\ \swarrow&\searrow\\ \blueD{x\text{-coordinate}}&\greenD{y\text{-coordinate}} \end{array}$

images.alt: A coordinate grid. A horizontal line moving right is labeled x-axis. A vertical line moving up from the x-axis is labeled y-axis. The point the lines intersect is labeled origin. Each axis has units labeled 1 to 4 from the origin.

hints.content: So, for $( \blueD{6}, \greenD{4})$, our $\blueD{x\text{-coordinate}}$ is $\blueD{6}$, and our $\greenD{y\text{-coordinate}}$ is $\greenD{4}$.
Let's start by going to $\blueD{6}$ on the $x$-axis:    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate grid. The x-axis is labeled 1 to 9. The y-axis is labeled 1 to 9. A blue arrow moves right along the x-axis from the origin to the 6.

hints.content: Now we go up to $\greenD{4}$ on the $y$-axis, and plot the point $(\blueD{6}, \greenD{4})$:   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate grid. The x-axis is labeled 1 to 9. The y-axis is labeled 1 to 9. A blue arrow moves right along the x-axis from the origin to the 6. A green arrow moves up 4 units from the 6 on the x-axis to align with 4 on the y-axis. A point labeled (6,4) is plotted at the end of the green arrow.

hints.content: Here is $(6,4)$ plotted on the coordinate plane.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate grid shows the ordered pair (6,4) plotted 6 units to the right and 4 units up from the origin.

hints.content: The **ordered pair** of a point tells us how to get to it from the origin.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{array}{cc} (\blueD{\text{distance right}},& \greenD{\text{distance up}})\\ \swarrow&\searrow\\ \blueD{x\text{-coordinate}}&\greenD{y\text{-coordinate}} \end{array}$

hints.content: Here is $(0,8)$ plotted on the coordinate plane.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate grid shows the ordered pair (0,8) plotted 8 units up from the origin.

hints.content: The **ordered pair** of a point tells us how to get to it from the origin.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{array}{cc} (\blueD{\text{distance right}},& \greenD{\text{distance up}})\\ \swarrow&\searrow\\ \blueD{x\text{-coordinate}}&\greenD{y\text{-coordinate}} \end{array}$

images.alt: A coordinate grid. A horizontal line moving right is labeled x-axis. A vertical line moving up from the x-axis is labeled y-axis. The point the lines intersect is labeled origin. Each axis has units labeled 1 to 4 from the origin.
